title: 112_s658
content: The "Support for Survivors Act" mandates the preservation of documentary evidence by the Department of Defense on incidents of sexual assault and harassment in the military. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, must identify the most effective means for the Department of Defense to preserve documentary evidence of sexual assault and harassment incidents in the military. This preservation method must be uniform across all military departments and include all relevant forms and documents. The Department of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, must establish means for preserving documentary evidence related to sexual assault and harassment incidents in the military. This preservation method should be consistent across all military departments and cover all relevant forms and documents. The Department of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, must establish means for preserving documentary evidence related to sexual assault and harassment incidents in the military. This includes ensuring full privacy protection for victims and granting lifetime access to the evidence for various purposes. The Department of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, must establish means for preserving documentary evidence related to sexual assault and harassment incidents in the military. This includes granting access to the evidence for research, reporting, training, and assisting individuals in submitting claims for benefits. The Department of Defense, in collaboration with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, must establish a method for preserving documentary evidence of sexual assault and harassment incidents in the military. This preservation should be in digitized, electronic form and may utilize existing document preservation methods. Additionally, a joint task force will be created by the Secretaries to recommend improvements in this area. A joint task force, composed of officers and employees from the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs, will recommend whether to establish a new form for documenting incidents of sexual assault and harassment in the military. The task force will submit a report with their recommendation to the Secretaries of Defense and Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Defense will submit a report to Congress within 180 days on preserving documentary evidence in incidents of sexual assault and harassment. The report will include a description of the preservation means and the work of the joint task force. The Secretary of Defense will implement means for preserving evidence on sexual assault and harassment incidents within 18 months of the Act's enactment. Recommendations for legislative or administrative action may also be included. The Secretary of Defense will establish means for preserving evidence on sexual assault and harassment incidents within 18 months of the Act's enactment. If necessary, interim measures may be utilized until full implementation is achieved. The Secretary of Defense will submit annual reports to Congress on the implementation of means for preserving documentary evidence by the military departments, including a description and assessment of the implementation and the number of individuals seeking documentary evidence. The Secretary of Defense will provide annual reports to Congress on efforts to inform Armed Forces members about preserving evidence for claims with the Department of Veterans Affairs. Recommendations for legislative or administrative action may be included. Definitions for covered incidents of sexual assault or harassment are also outlined. The term "covered incident of sexual assault or sexual harassment" refers to incidents involving a member of the Armed Forces as the victim. Sexual assault includes rape, sexual assault, other sexual misconduct under section 920 of title 10, United States Code, sodomy, intentional sexual contact with force or without consent, and unwanted sexual contact. The term "sexual harassment" in the Armed Forces involves unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, or other sexual conduct that interferes with a person's service, pay, or promotion. It also includes any attempt to commit such acts. Sexual harassment in the Armed Forces involves conduct that interferes with a person's duty or creates a hostile environment.
